I'd even say some shades of Hitchcock...this is clearly better than MMM, which is seen as a guilty pleasure by some if not most Woody fans.
Takes what could be an overly cute and sentimental romance (based on Dostoyevsky's story) and turns it into an amusing and very touching road movie with one of Woody's most beautiful shots as Victor Chaplin pulls the car up to the windswept villa on top of a hill.

Well,I am a dancer so automatically I liked this film. The only thing I didn't like was they didn't have much dancing as I thought there would be, replacing some of it with the puppet show(which I thought was hilarious by the way) other then that the movie was great, very funny especially Will Smith as Arthur. Then we meet Belize who is hilarious and makes the movie more fun, Sometimes creepy, whimsical and funny!

I had mixed feelings for "Les Valseuses" (1974) written and directed by Bertrand Blier when I started watching it but I ended up loving it. "Les Valseuses" was originally a novel of the same title. The film version is written and directed by Bertrand Blier and I think any readers of the book will also be fascinated enough to know that "Les Valseuses" is part of an autobiography.
